FDA could green light new Covid boosters as early as FridayNBCNews6/27/2024

The Food and Drug Administration plans to greenlight updated versions of the Covid boosters, according to some familiar with the agency's plans. The cost of the shots will also no longer be covered by the federal government.

Read

type="application/ld+json">{"@context":{"@vocab":"http://schema.org","articleId":{"@id":"Text","@type":"@id"},"topics":{"@id":"Text","@type":"@id"}},"@type":"NewsArticle","headline":"FDA could greenlight new Covid boosters as early as Friday","url":"https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/fda-green-light-new-covid-boosters-early-friday-rcna103379","thumbnailUrl":"https://media-cldnry.s-nbcnews.com/image/upload/t_social_share_1024x768_scale,f_auto,q_auto:best/rockcms/2022-12/221201-covid-booster-ew-541p-3a2e3b.jpg","alternativeHeadline":"FDA could greenlight new Covid boosters as early as Friday","articleBody":"The Food and Drug Administration plans to greenlight updated versions of the Covid boosters as early as Friday, according to four people familiar with the agency’s plans. The latest shots are designed to target the XBB.1.5 omicron subvariant. Though that strain is no longer dominant, the boosters should still protect against current circulating subvariants, which are closely related, the drugmakers and experts say.  The Friday timeline for authorization is not firm, and it could slide into early next week, two of the sources said.  That could prompt further criticism from some doctors who say federal health agencies are acting too slowly in the booster rollout as Covid cases and hospitalizations are once again rising.  Two sources indicated the FDA is exploring the possibility of granting the boosters a full approval license instead of an emergency use authorization, a departure from the approach used for previous Covid vaccine authorizations. However, it remains uncertain whether that is still the intended course of action. After the FDA’s signoff, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and its advisory committee will issue their own recommendations about who should get the shots and how they should be used. The agency’s Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices is expected to vote at a scheduled meeting Tuesday. The CDC’s director, Dr. Mandy Cohen, could sign off on the boosters shortly after the meeting, allowing vaccinations to begin. About 97% of adults have some level of protective immunity, according to data shared by government officials. However, because immunity from previous infections and vaccinations diminishes over time, officials aim to shore up protection as people spend more time indoors during the fall and the winter. For the first time since Covid vaccines have been available, however, the cost of the shots will not be covered by the federal government.  Pfizer and Moderna have indicated the list price for the vaccines will be $110 to $130 per dose.  Whether and when someone will be able to get the shots will depend on their insurance coverage, said Jennifer Kates, the director of the Global Health & HIV Policy Program at KFF, a nonprofit health policy organization. Most people with private and public health insurance should continue to pay nothing out of pocket for the vaccines, Kates said. If a person gets the vaccine out of network, however, it could carry a cost.  Some people without insurance may be able to get boosters free from safety net providers, such as community health centers, but others may have to pay the full cost. The Biden administration has also announced a “bridge” program that will offer uninsured people access to free boosters at least through the end of 2024. Novavax’s vaccine, which has not been granted full FDA approval yet but instead is available through emergency use authorization, will continue to be covered, Kates said.  Follow NBC HEALTH on Twitter & Facebook. ","dateCreated":"2023-09-06T18:33:06.000Z","datePublished":"2023-09-06T18:33:06.000Z","dateModified":"2023-09-06T18:33:06.000Z","articleSection":"health","articleId":"rcna103379","identifier":{"@type":"PropertyValue","propertyID":"uid","value":"rcna103379"},"topics":"","image":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://media-cldnry.s-nbcnews.com/image/upload/t_fit-1500w,f_auto,q_auto:best/rockcms/2022-12/221201-covid-booster-ew-541p-3a2e3b.jpg","caption":"A Jackson-Hinds Comprehensive Health Center nurse administers a Pfizer Covid-19 booster vaccine at an inoculation station next to Jackson State University in Jackson, Miss., on Nov. 18, 2022"},"author":[{"@context":"https://schema.org/","@type":"Person","name":"Berkeley Lovelace Jr. ","image":"https://media-cldnry.s-nbcnews.com/image/upload/t_fit-1500w,f_auto,q_auto:best/newscms/2023_08/3595665/berkeley-lovelace-byline-jm-1.jpg","jobTitle":null,"description":"Berkeley Lovelace Jr. is a health and medical reporter for NBC News. class="article-body__date-source" data-testid="article-body-timestamp"><time class="relative z-1" dateTime="2023-09-06T18:33:06.027Z" data-testid="timestamp__datePublished" content="2023-09-06T18:33:06.027Z">Sept. 6, 2023, 6:33 PM UTC</time></div><div class="article-inline-byline" data-activity-map="inline-byline-article-top">By <span class="byline-name" data-testid="byline-name"><a href="https://www.nbcnews.com/author/berkeley-lovelace-jr-ncpn1284341">Berkeley Lovelace Jr.</a></span> and <span class="byline-name" data-testid="byline-name"><a href="https://www.nbcnews.com/author/monica-alba-ncpn3696">Monica Alba</a></span></div></section><div class="article-body__content"><p class="">The Food and Drug Administration plans to greenlight updated versions of the Covid boosters as early as Friday, according to four people familiar with the agency’s plans.</p><p class="">The latest shots are designed to target the XBB.1.5 omicron subvariant. Though that strain is no longer dominant, the boosters should still <a href="https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/new-covid-vaccine-2023-ba286-variant-moderna-rcna103603" target="_blank">protect against current circulating subvariants</a>, which are closely related, the drugmakers and experts say. </p><div class="ad ad--text-alignment ad-container boxinlineAd dn-print" data-testid="ad__container"><div data-mps="true" data-slot="boxinline" data-sizes="[[[1000,1],[]],[[758,1],[[300,250],[700,50],[5,5],[728,90],[360,360]]],[[0,0],[[300,250],[700,50],[5,5],[360,360]]]]" data-render-on-view="true" data-targeting="{}" data-active-tab="true" data-offset-viewport="100" data-testid="ad__container__inner"></div></div><div id="taboolaReadMoreBelow"></div><p class="">The Friday timeline for authorization is not firm, and it could slide into early next week, two of the sources said. </p><p class="">That could prompt<a href="https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/expect-covid-booster-shot-eris-subvariant-spreads-rcna101597"> further criticism from some doctors</a> who say federal health agencies are acting too slowly in the booster rollout as <a href="https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/signs-point-rise-covid-rcna103439" target="_blank">Covid cases and hospitalizations are once again rising</a>. </p><p class="">Two sources indicated the FDA is exploring the possibility of granting the boosters a full approval license instead of an emergency use authorization, a departure from the approach used for previous Covid vaccine authorizations. However, it remains uncertain whether that is still the intended course of action.</p><p class="">After the FDA’s signoff, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and its advisory committee will issue their own recommendations about who should get the shots and how they should be used. The agency’s Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices is expected to vote at a <a href="https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2023/08/25/2023-18288/advisory-committee-on-immunization-practices">scheduled meeting</a> Tuesday. The CDC’s director, Dr. Mandy Cohen, could sign off on the boosters shortly after the meeting, allowing vaccinations to begin.</p><div class="ad ad--text-alignment ad-container boxinlineAd dn-print" data-testid="ad__container"><div data-mps="true" data-slot="boxinline" data-sizes="[[[1000,1],[]],[[758,1],[[300,250],[700,50],[5,5],[728,90],[360,360]]],[[0,0],[[300,250],[700,50],[5,5],[360,360]]]]" data-render-on-view="true" data-targeting="{}" data-active-tab="true" data-offset-viewport="100" data-testid="ad__container__inner"></div></div><p class="">About 97% of adults have some level of protective immunity, according to data shared by government officials. However, because immunity from previous infections and vaccinations diminishes over time, officials aim to shore up protection as people spend more time indoors during the fall and the winter.</p><p class="">For the first time since Covid vaccines have been available, however, the cost of the shots will not be covered by the federal government. </p><div class="recommended-intersection-ref" data-activity-map="recommended-article-body-recommended" data-testid="recommended-wrapper"></div><div class="recommended-intersection-ref" data-activity-map="recommended-article-body-recommended" data-testid="recommended-wrapper"></div><p class="">Pfizer and Moderna have indicated the list price for the vaccines will be <a href="https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/pfizer-plans-sell-covid-vaccines-110-130-dose-rcna53382">$110 to $130 per dose</a>. </p><p class="">Whether and when someone will be able to get the shots <a href="https://www.kff.org/coronavirus-covid-19/issue-brief/commercialization-of-covid-19-vaccines-treatments-and-tests-implications-for-access-and-coverage/#:~:text=While%20COVID%2D19%20vaccines%2C%20including,and%20tests%2C%20where%20cost%20sharing">will depend on their insurance coverage</a>, said Jennifer Kates, the director of the Global Health & HIV Policy Program at KFF, a nonprofit health policy organization.</p><p class="">Most people with private and public health insurance should continue to pay nothing out of pocket for the vaccines, Kates said. If a person gets the vaccine out of network, however, it could carry a cost. </p><p class="">Some people without insurance may be able to get boosters free from safety net providers, such as community health centers, but others may have to pay the full cost. The Biden administration has also announced a “bridge” program that will offer uninsured people access to free boosters at least through the end of 2024.</p><div class="ad ad--text-alignment ad-container boxinlineAd dn-print" data-testid="ad__container"><div data-mps="true" data-slot="boxinline" data-sizes="[[[1000,1],[]],[[758,1],[[300,250],[700,50],[5,5],[728,90],[360,360]]],[[0,0],[[300,250],[700,50],[5,5],[360,360]]]]" data-render-on-view="true" data-targeting="{}" data-active-tab="true" data-offset-viewport="100" data-testid="ad__container__inner"></div></div><p class="">Novavax’s vaccine, which has not been granted full FDA approval yet but instead is available through emergency use authorization, will continue to be covered, Kates said. </p><p class="endmark"><strong><em>Follow </em></strong><a href="https://www.nbcnews.com/health"><strong><em>NBC HEALTH</em></strong></a><strong><em> on </em></strong><a href="https://twitter.com/NBCNewsHealth"><strong><em>Twitter</em></strong></a><strong><em> & </em></strong><a href="https://www.facebook.com/NBCNewsHealth/"><strong><em>Facebook</em></strong></a>. </p></div><div class="article-body__content"><div class="expanded-byline-contributors shots could become available next week, after the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention also signs off. ","content":{"text":["The Food and Drug Administration plans to greenlight updated versions of the Covid boosters as early as Friday, according to four people familiar with the agency’s plans.","The latest shots are designed to target the XBB.1.5 omicron subvariant. Though that strain is no longer dominant, the boosters should still protect against current circulating subvariants, which are closely related, the drugmakers and experts say. ","The Friday timeline for authorization is not firm, and it could slide into early next week, two of the sources said. ","That could prompt further criticism from some doctors who say federal health agencies are acting too slowly in the booster rollout as Covid cases and hospitalizations are once again rising. ","Two sources indicated the FDA is exploring the possibility of granting the boosters a full approval license instead of an emergency use authorization, a departure from the approach used for previous Covid vaccine authorizations. However, it remains uncertain whether that is still the intended course of action.","After the FDA’s signoff, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and its advisory committee will issue their own recommendations about who should get the shots and how they should be used. The agency’s Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices is expected to vote at a scheduled meeting Tuesday. The CDC’s director, Dr. Mandy Cohen, could sign off on the boosters shortly after the meeting, allowing vaccinations to begin.","About 97% of adults have some level of protective immunity, according to data shared by government officials. However, because immunity from previous infections and vaccinations diminishes over time, officials aim to shore up protection as people spend more time indoors during the fall and the winter.","For the first time since Covid vaccines have been available, however, the cost of the shots will not be covered by the federal government. ","Pfizer and Moderna have indicated the list price for the vaccines will be $110 to $130 per dose. ","Whether and when someone will be able to get the shots will depend on their insurance coverage, said Jennifer Kates, the director of the Global Health \u0026 HIV Policy Program at KFF, a nonprofit health policy organization.","Most people with private and public health insurance should continue to pay nothing out of pocket for the vaccines, Kates said. If a person gets the vaccine out of network, however, it could carry a cost. ","Some people without insurance may be able to get boosters free from safety net providers, such as community health centers, but others may have to pay the full cost. The Biden administration has also announced a “bridge” program that will offer uninsured people access to free boosters at least through the end of 2024.","Novavax’s vaccine, which has not been granted full FDA approval yet but instead is available through emergency use authorization, will continue to be covered, Kates said. ","Follow NBC HEALTH on Twitter \u0026 Facebook. "]},"documentTracing":{"currentMessageId":{"id":"b004fe0a-8f7c-4636-b828-145f80cb7ddd","updatedDate":"Thu Sep 07 2023 20:31:54 GMT+0000 Though that strain is no longer dominant, the boosters should still \u003ca href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/new-covid-vaccine-2023-ba286-variant-moderna-rcna103603\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eprotect against current circulating subvariants\u003c/a\u003e, which are closely related, the drugmakers and experts say. "},{"type":"markup","element":"p","html":"The Friday timeline for authorization is not firm, and it could slide into early next week, two of the sources said. "},{"type":"markup","element":"p","html":"That could prompt\u003ca href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/expect-covid-booster-shot-eris-subvariant-spreads-rcna101597\"\u003e further criticism from some doctors\u003c/a\u003e who say federal health agencies are acting too slowly in the booster rollout as \u003ca href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/signs-point-rise-covid-rcna103439\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eCovid cases and hospitalizations are once again rising\u003c/a\u003e. "},{"type":"markup","element":"p","html":"Two sources indicated the FDA is exploring the possibility of granting the boosters a full approval license instead of an emergency use authorization, a departure from the approach used for previous Covid vaccine authorizations. However, it remains uncertain whether that is still the intended course of action."},{"type":"markup","element":"p","html":"After the FDA’s signoff, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and its advisory committee will issue their own recommendations about who should get the shots and how they should be used. The agency’s Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices is expected to vote at a \u003ca href=\"https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2023/08/25/2023-18288/advisory-committee-on-immunization-practices\"\u003escheduled meeting\u003c/a\u003e Tuesday. The CDC’s director, Dr. Mandy Cohen, could sign off on the boosters shortly after the meeting, allowing vaccinations to begin."},{"type":"markup","element":"p","html":"About 97% of adults have some level of protective immunity, according to data shared by government officials. However, because immunity from previous infections and vaccinations diminishes over time, officials aim to shore up protection as people spend more time indoors during the fall and the winter."},{"type":"markup","element":"p","html":"For the first time since Covid vaccines have been available, however, the cost of the shots will not be covered by the federal government. "},{"type":"markup","element":"p","html":"Pfizer and Moderna have indicated the list price for the vaccines will be \u003ca href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/pfizer-plans-sell-covid-vaccines-110-130-dose-rcna53382\"\u003e$110 to $130 per dose\u003c/a\u003e. "},{"type":"markup","element":"p","html":"Whether and when someone will be able to get the shots \u003ca href=\"https://www.kff.org/coronavirus-covid-19/issue-brief/commercialization-of-covid-19-vaccines-treatments-and-tests-implications-for-access-and-coverage/#:~:text=While%20COVID%2D19%20vaccines%2C%20including,and%20tests%2C%20where%20cost%20sharing\"\u003ewill depend on their insurance coverage\u003c/a\u003e, said Jennifer Kates, the director of the Global Health \u0026 HIV Policy Program at KFF, a nonprofit health policy organization."},{"type":"markup","element":"p","html":"Most people with private and public health insurance should continue to pay nothing out of pocket for the vaccines, Kates said. If a person gets the vaccine out of network, however, it could carry a cost. "},{"type":"markup","element":"p","html":"Some people without insurance may be able to get boosters free from safety net providers, such as community health centers, but others may have to pay the full cost. The Biden administration has also announced a “bridge” program that will offer uninsured people access to free boosters at least through the end of 2024."},{"type":"markup","element":"p","html":"Novavax’s vaccine, which has not been granted full FDA approval yet but instead is available through emergency use authorization, will continue to be readabilityObject.title: FDA could green light new Covid boosters as early as Friday
readabilityObject.content:
The Food and Drug Administration plans to greenlight updated versions of the Covid boosters as early as Friday, according to four people familiar with the agency’s plans.

The latest shots are designed to target the XBB.1.5 omicron subvariant. Though that strain is no longer dominant, the boosters should still protect against current circulating subvariants, which are closely related, the drugmakers and experts say. 

The Friday timeline for authorization is not firm, and it could slide into early next week, two of the sources said. 

That could prompt further criticism from some doctors who say federal health agencies are acting too slowly in the booster rollout as Covid cases and hospitalizations are once again rising. 

Two sources indicated the FDA is exploring the possibility of granting the boosters a full approval license instead of an emergency use authorization, a departure from the approach used for previous Covid vaccine authorizations. However, it remains uncertain whether that is still the intended course of action.

After the FDA’s signoff, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and its advisory committee will issue their own recommendations about who should get the shots and how they should be used. The agency’s Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices is expected to vote at a scheduled meeting Tuesday. The CDC’s director, Dr. Mandy Cohen, could sign off on the boosters shortly after the meeting, allowing vaccinations to begin.

About 97% of adults have some level of protective immunity, according to data shared by government officials. However, because immunity from previous infections and vaccinations diminishes over time, officials aim to shore up protection as people spend more time indoors during the fall and the winter.

For the first time since Covid vaccines have been available, however, the cost of the shots will not be covered by the federal government. 

Pfizer and Moderna have indicated the list price for the vaccines will be $110 to $130 per dose. 

Whether and when someone will be able to get the shots will depend on their insurance coverage, said Jennifer Kates, the director of the Global Health & HIV Policy Program at KFF, a nonprofit health policy organization.

Most people with private and public health insurance should continue to pay nothing out of pocket for the vaccines, Kates said. If a person gets the vaccine out of network, however, it could carry a cost. 

Some people without insurance may be able to get boosters free from safety net providers, such as community health centers, but others may have to pay the full cost. The Biden administration has also announced a “bridge” program that will offer uninsured people access to free boosters at least through the end of 2024.

Novavax’s vaccine, which has not been granted full FDA approval yet but instead is available through emergency use authorization, will continue to be covered, Kates said. 

Follow NBC HEALTH on Twitter & Facebook. 

Berkeley Lovelace Jr.

Berkeley Lovelace Jr. is a health and medical reporter for NBC News. He covers the Food and Drug Administration, with a special focus on Covid vaccines, prescription drug pricing and health care. He previously covered the biotech and pharmaceutical industry with CNBC.

Monica Alba

Monica Alba is a White House correspondent for NBC News.

Erika Edwards

and

Patrick Martin

contributed

.
